awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel for 2024 USENIX Conferences USENIX ATC 2024 and OSDI 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Association presents conferences at the forefront of computing innovation and research that build collaborations between researchers and practitioners from industry, government, and academia. These events provide educational, mentorship, and networking opportunities of very high value to graduate students in the computer sciences who attend. To help increase the representation and participation of these students, this proposal provides funding to assist approximately 34 US-based graduate students to attend each of the following events:

● 2024 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (ATC ‘24)
● 18th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI ‘24)


The knowledge shared and advanced at these conferences has practical and meaningful application to many tools used in daily life, as well as to the ethical, cultural, and social ramifications of computing technology. This grant allows the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conference and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. USENIX is an open access organization, and all research and results presented and published at these events are freely available to the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
USENIX Outcomes Report, USENIX ATC ‘24 and OSDI ‘24

This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in July 2024, specifically the 2024 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC ‘24) and the 18th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI ‘24).

USENIX ATC ‘24 took place July 10-12, 2024 in Santa Clara, CA. The event brought together leading systems researchers for the presentation of cutting-edge systems research and the opportunity to gain insight into a wealth of must-know topics, including virtualization, system and network management and troubleshooting, cloud and edge computing, security, privacy, and trust, mobile and wireless, and more. OSDI ‘24 also occurred on July 10-12, 2024 in Santa Clara (co-located with USENIX ATC ‘24). OSDI gathered professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds in a premier forum to discuss the design, implementation, and implications of systems software. The symposium emphasizes innovative research and quantified or insightful experiences in systems design and implementation.

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and essential part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of students who would otherwise have been unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers. Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, poster sessions, and receptions. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code providing full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with costs related to travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before completing payments. 

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster),

  • Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant’s research,

  • Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,

  • Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities,

  • Degree program (graduate students prioritized) and financial need.

NSF funds supported a total of 45 grants for students to participate in USENIX ATC ‘24 and OSDI ‘24.  The financial support from NSF allowed us to grant awards to many more qualified students than we would have been able to otherwise. 

  • For USENIX ATC ‘24, USENIX received 43 grant applications from students and awarded 25 grants. The NSF funds of $13,100 covered 11 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university. There were 165 attendees at USENIX ATC ‘24, which included 56 students. USENIX ATC ‘24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options. 

  • For OSDI ‘24, USENIX received 68 grant applications from students and awarded 50 student grants. The NSF funds of $36,900 covered 34 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. There were 358 attendees at OSDI ‘24, which included 125 students. OSDI ‘24 was also held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options. 


Last Modified: 10/28/2024
Modified by: Catherine Bergman

Image
  • Some of the students who received student grants to attend USENIX ATC '24 and OSDI '24. Participation in the group photo is optional.

USENIX Outcomes Report, USENIX ATC 24 and OSDI 24


This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in July 2024, specifically the 2024 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (USENIX ATC 24) and the 18th USENIX Symposium on Operating Systems Design and Implementation (OSDI 24).


USENIX ATC 24 took place July 10-12, 2024 in Santa Clara, CA. The event brought together leading systems researchers for the presentation of cutting-edge systems research and the opportunity to gain insight into a wealth of must-know topics, including virtualization, system and network management and troubleshooting, cloud and edge computing, security, privacy, and trust, mobile and wireless, and more. OSDI 24 also occurred on July 10-12, 2024 in Santa Clara (co-located with USENIX ATC 24). OSDI gathered professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds in a premier forum to discuss the design, implementation, and implications of systems software. The symposium emphasizes innovative research and quantified or insightful experiences in systems design and implementation.


Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and essential part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field and exposes students to leading-edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of students who would otherwise have been unable to attend the conferences and extended the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers. Students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including a student meetup, poster sessions, and receptions.


Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. USENIX covered registration costs by providing grant recipients with a code providing full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided payment to assist with costs related to travel and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depended on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested. We confirmed that grant recipients registered and attended the relevant event before completing payments.


The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:




Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics,




Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster),




Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicants research,




Application history, prioritizing first-time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months,




Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events,




Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities,




Degree program (graduate students prioritized) and financial need.




NSF funds supported a total of 45 grants for students to participate in USENIX ATC 24 and OSDI 24. The financial support from NSF allowed us to grant awards to many more qualified students than we would have been able to otherwise.




For USENIX ATC 24, USENIX received 43 grant applications from students and awarded 25 grants. The NSF funds of $13,100 covered 11 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a US university. There were 165 attendees at USENIX ATC 24, which included 56 students. USENIX ATC 24 was held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options.






For OSDI 24, USENIX received 68 grant applications from students and awarded 50 student grants. The NSF funds of $36,900 covered 34 of these grants. Each grantee receiving an NSF-supported grant was enrolled at a U.S. university. There were 358 attendees at OSDI 24, which included 125 students. OSDI 24 was also held entirely in-person, with no virtual attendance options.
